content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Find on Apple website how many types of AirPods (3rd generation) are available and what is the price difference.  Please interact with https://www.apple.com/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)
Clicked the “AirPods” link in the global navigation to navigate to the AirPods section of Apple’s site.
Format ERROR: Both 'Thought' and 'Action' should be included in your reply.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to navigate from the current Apple Watch page to the AirPods section to locate information about AirPods (3rd generation). The global navigation includes an “AirPods” link.
Action: Click [64]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need information specific to AirPods (3rd generation). The “Compare AirPods models” link should list each model and its variants, helping identify how many versions of the 3rd‑generation AirPods there are and their prices.
Action: Click [9030]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to open the first combobox to change model from “AirPods 4 with Active Noise Cancellation” to “AirPods (3rd generation)” to view its pricing.
Action: Click [12036]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The combobox is open; I need to view its dropdown options to select “AirPods (3rd generation)”. Scrolling the window may reveal the list of options if it isn’t yet visible in the tree.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown list from the expanded combobox isn’t yet visible in the snippet; it may be located further down (or rendered as an overlay). Scrolling further should reveal the list options, including “AirPods (3rd generation)”.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: “See all models” button should let me choose AirPods (3rd generation) directly instead of using the dropdown.
Action: Click [13313]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to continue scrolling the page to locate the popup list that belongs to the expanded combobox; the menu is likely rendered further down in the DOM and not yet visible.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu for the expanded combobox may actually be positioned above the current viewport; scrolling up could reveal its list of options (including “AirPods (3rd generation)”).
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to get back to the main AirPods product section to see the “AirPods (3rd generation)” purchasing page, which should list its variants and prices. Scrolling to the very top will reveal the global navigation bar where I can click “AirPods”.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The combobox in the first column is expanded; its dropdown menu (role "menu") should be somewhere above in the DOM but isn’t visible yet in the tree extract. Scrolling further up may bring that overlay (menu) into view so that I can select “AirPods (3rd generation)”.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “See all models” button (13313) should open a model-selection overlay that will let me choose AirPods (3rd generation) directly, making it easier to view its pricing.  
Action: Click [13313]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “All AirPods models” dialog is open and currently shows AirPods 4 models; I need to scroll further down within the dialog to reach the AirPods (3rd generation) entries.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: In the “All AirPods models” dialog, I haven’t yet reached the AirPods (3rd generation) section; scrolling down further within this dialog should reveal it.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to scroll inside the “All AirPods models” dialog (element 22380) to reach the AirPods (3rd generation) section.  
Action: Scroll [22380]; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Still inside the “All AirPods models” dialog (22380); AirPods (3rd generation) hasn’t appeared yet, so continue scrolling down within this dialog.  
Action: Scroll [22380]; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: AirPods (3rd generation) still not visible in the dialog list; need to continue scrolling down inside the “All AirPods models” dialog to reach it.  
Action: Scroll [22380]; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: AirPods (3rd generation) still hasn’t appeared in the “All AirPods models” dialog, so I need to scroll further down inside that dialog to reach it.  
Action: Scroll [22380]; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: AirPods (3rd generation) header is now visible in the dialog, but the price details are likely just below. I should scroll a bit further inside this dialog to reveal the pricing lines for both versions.
Action: Scroll [22380]; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To locate the price line for AirPods (3rd generation), I need to look just above its “AirPods (3rd generation)” figure inside the same dialog. A small upward scroll within the dialog should reveal the price text.
Action: Scroll [22380]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I’m still inside the “All AirPods models” dialog (element 22380). The price text for AirPods (3rd generation) should appear just above the product figure, so I need to move farther up in this dialog to reach the pricing line.
Action: Scroll [22380]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The price for AirPods (3rd generation) should be just below its figure (element 22761). Scrolling a bit further down in the dialog will surface that price.
Action: Scroll [22380]; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The AirPods (3rd generation) item is in view, but its price (which should appear just below the figure, like the patterns for “Pro 2” and “Max”) isn’t yet visible. Scrolling further down inside the “All AirPods models” dialog should reveal the price lines.
Action: Scroll [22380]; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The price for AirPods (3rd generation) is likely just above the figure we see in the dialog; scrolling upward a little inside this “All AirPods models” dialog should reveal the price line.
Action: Scroll [22380]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to scroll upward within the “All AirPods models” dialog (element 22380) to locate the price line that should appear just above/below the “AirPods (3rd generation)” figure.  
Action: Scroll [22380]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Price lines appear just above each model’s figure. I still don’t see AirPods (3rd generation) prices; scrolling further upward in the dialog should reveal a “$169” and “$179” line above its figure.  
Action: Scroll [22380]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The price for AirPods (3rd generation) should be a StaticText dollar amount located a bit further upward in this “All AirPods models” dialog. I need to keep scrolling up inside the dialog to reveal it.  
Action: Scroll [22380]; up

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.
